Spanish: Alargué mi viaje un día más me voy el viernes
New_English: I extended my trip one more day I'm leaving on Friday
Cultural_Context: Common phrase when travel plans change. 'Alargar' means to extend/prolong. Colombians often give specific details about departure days.
Example_Sentence: Me gustó tanto Cartagena que alargué mi viaje - la ciudad me enamoró.
Colombian_Notes: Used in romantic contexts when someone extends their stay to spend more time with someone special. The incomplete Spanish suggests 'viernes' (Friday).

Spanish: Con solo mirarte se me olvida hasta mi nombre
New_English: Just by looking at you I forget even my own name
Cultural_Context: Romantic pick-up line using the 'se me' construction to express involuntary action. Very Colombian flirting style - poetic and exaggerated.
Example_Sentence: Con solo mirarte se me olvida hasta mi nombre - eres tan hermosa que me tienes hipnotizado.
Colombian_Notes: Classic Colombian romantic expression. 'Se me olvida' = it slips my mind (unintentional). Used when someone's beauty is so captivating it's disorienting.

Spanish: Eres como Cartagena hermosa y me quiero perder en ti
New_English: You're like Cartagena beautiful and I want to get lost in you
Cultural_Context: Romantic metaphor comparing person to Cartagena, Colombia's most romantic city. 'Perderme' = get lost/lose myself. Strong romantic/sexual innuendo.
Example_Sentence: Eres como Cartagena hermosa y me quiero perder en ti toda la noche.
Colombian_Notes: Poetic Colombian flirting. Cartagena = romance/beauty. 'Perderme en ti' has dual meaning: explore you deeply OR get lost in passion. Very sensual.

Spanish: Estoy practicando español ahora hasta que sea fluido
New_English: I'm practicing Spanish now until I become fluent
Cultural_Context: Shows commitment to language learning. 'Hasta que' + subjunctive expresses future goal. Often used in dating contexts to impress Colombian partner.
Example_Sentence: Estoy practicando español ahora hasta que sea fluido - quiero poder expresarte todo lo que siento.
Colombian_Notes: Romantic angle: learning Spanish to communicate better with romantic interest. 'Fluido' = fluent. Shows dedication and cultural appreciation.

New_English: I'm turned on gently everything's good
Cultural_Context: 'Prendido' = turned on/aroused (lit: turned on like a light). 'Suave' softens it. Colombian way of expressing attraction casually without being too aggressive.
Example_Sentence: Estoy prendido suave todo bien - me gustas pero vamos tranquilos.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian slang for aroused but keeping it chill. 'Prendido' can mean drunk OR sexually excited. Context matters. 'Suave' = smooth/gentle/easy.

New_English: I'm deeply infatuated / I'm fallen hard
Cultural_Context: 'Tragado' (lit: swallowed) = completely smitten/head over heels. Very Colombian slang. More intense than 'enamorado'. Implies loss of control.
Example_Sentence: Estoy tragado de ti - no puedo dejar de pensar en ti ni un segundo.
Colombian_Notes: Strong Colombian expression for intense infatuation. 'Tragado' suggests being consumed by feelings. Used when attraction is overwhelming and obvious.

New_English: Thanks but I'll pass this time
Cultural_Context: Polite decline using 'pasar' = to pass/skip. Colombian indirect communication style - softening rejection with gratitude.
Example_Sentence: Gracias pero esta vez paso - no me siento bien hoy. Mejor otro día.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian politeness: thank first, then decline. 'Esta vez' leaves door open for future. Used for declining dates, drinks, activities.

New_English: Thanks for trusting me
Cultural_Context: Expression of gratitude for emotional intimacy. Trust is highly valued in Colombian relationships. Often used after someone shares something personal.
Example_Sentence: Gracias por confiar en mí y contarme lo que te pasó - estoy aquí para ti.
Colombian_Notes: Important in building romantic intimacy. Colombians value confianza (trust) deeply. Used when partner opens up emotionally or physically.

Spanish: Gracias por cuidarme por estar pendiente
New_English: Thanks for taking care of me for being attentive
Cultural_Context: 'Cuidar' = take care. 'Estar pendiente' = be attentive/aware. Colombian relationships emphasize caregiving and attentiveness.
Example_Sentence: Gracias por cuidarme por estar pendiente - eres muy especial para mí.
Colombian_Notes: 'Estar pendiente' is key Colombian value in relationships - being aware of partner's needs. Shows appreciation for emotional labor.

Spanish: Gracias por decirme cómo te sientes
New_English: Thanks for telling me how you feel
Cultural_Context: Appreciation for emotional honesty. Colombian culture can be indirect, so directly expressing feelings is valued and acknowledged.
Example_Sentence: Gracias por decirme cómo te sientes - me ayuda a entenderte mejor.
Colombian_Notes: Encourages emotional vulnerability. Important in Colombian dating where indirect communication is common. Values openness.

New_English: Thanks for existing
Cultural_Context: Romantic expression of gratitude for partner's mere existence. Very Colombian romantic style - poetic and emotionally expressive.
Example_Sentence: Gracias por existir mi amor - mi vida es mejor desde que te conocí.
Colombian_Notes: Deep romantic sentiment. Colombian culture embraces dramatic romantic expressions. Used to express that someone's presence makes life meaningful.

Spanish: Gracias por todo eres un gran ser humano
New_English: Thanks for everything you're a great human being
Cultural_Context: Wholesome appreciation recognizing someone's character. 'Ser humano' emphasizes their humanity and goodness beyond romantic interest.
Example_Sentence: Gracias por todo eres un gran ser humano - valoro mucho tu amistad y tu corazón.
Colombian_Notes: Can be romantic or platonic. Colombian way of recognizing someone's inherent worth. 'Gran ser humano' = great person at their core.

Spanish: Gracias por tu mensaje tan lindo mi amor
New_English: Thanks for your beautiful message my love
Cultural_Context: Affectionate response to sweet text. 'Lindo' = beautiful/sweet. 'Mi amor' is common term of endearment even in casual Colombian dating.
Example_Sentence: Gracias por tu mensaje tan lindo mi amor - me alegró el día.
Colombian_Notes: Colombians are expressive via text. 'Mi amor' used early in dating. 'Lindo' shows appreciation for thoughtfulness. Text culture is strong.

Spanish: Gracias por tu tiempo y tu cariño
New_English: Thanks for your time and your affection
Cultural_Context: Acknowledges both practical (time) and emotional (affection) investment. 'Cariño' = affection/care. Colombian relationships value quality time.
Example_Sentence: Gracias por tu tiempo y tu cariño - sé que estás ocupado y valoro que hagas espacio para mí.
Colombian_Notes: 'Cariño' is lighter than 'amor' but deeper than 'gusto'. Recognizes that time is love language. Colombian dating values presence.

Spanish: Hoy estoy cansadito te parece si dejamos para otro día
New_English: Today I'm a bit tired how about we leave it for another day
Cultural_Context: Gentle proposal to reschedule. 'Cansadito' (diminutive) softens 'tired'. 'Te parece si' = how about if - Colombian polite suggestion style.
Example_Sentence: Hoy estoy cansadito te parece si dejamos para otro día - quiero estar con energía para ti.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian indirect communication: diminutive softens. 'Te parece si' shows consideration. Not canceling, postponing thoughtfully.

New_English: Today I'm deeply infatuated with you
Cultural_Context: Intense expression using 'tragado' = swallowed up by feelings. Emphasizing current state with 'hoy'. Playful way to express strong attraction.
Example_Sentence: Hoy estoy tragado de ti - no sé qué me hiciste pero no puedo concentrarme en nada más.
Colombian_Notes: 'Tragado' stronger than enamorado. Colombian slang for can't stop thinking about someone. Often used playfully to show vulnerability.

New_English: Today I'm going to punish you
Cultural_Context: Sexual/playful threat. 'Castigar' = punish. Used flirtatiously in intimate contexts. Tone and relationship context determine if playful or serious.
Example_Sentence: Hoy te voy a castigar por hacerme esperar tanto - ya vas a ver.
Colombian_Notes: Sexually playful Colombian expression. 'Castigar' implies playful dominance. Used in established intimate relationships with consent and flirting.

New_English: I had a really good time thanks
Cultural_Context: Post-date appreciation. 'Pasarla bien' = have a good time. Colombian politeness: acknowledge experience and show gratitude.
Example_Sentence: La pasé muy bien gracias - me encantó conocerte mejor.
Colombian_Notes: Standard Colombian post-date message. Shows appreciation and interest. Sets up potential for next date. 'La pasé' = the time I spent.

Spanish: Lo puedo cambiar si no me queda
New_English: I can exchange it if it doesn't fit me
Cultural_Context: Shopping phrase but used metaphorically in dating = flexibility. 'Quedar' = fit. Shows adaptability and openness to change.
Example_Sentence: Lo puedo cambiar si no me queda - no te preocupes estoy flexible con los planes.
Colombian_Notes: Practical phrase about clothing but shows Colombian flexibility. Can be metaphor for relationship willingness to adjust/accommodate.

Spanish: Me gusta cómo suena tu español quiero aprender más
New_English: I like how your Spanish sounds I want to learn more
Cultural_Context: Flirty compliment about language. Shows interest in partner's culture/language. 'Suena' = sounds. Colombian appreciation for linguistic effort.
Example_Sentence: Me gusta cómo suena tu español quiero aprender más - enséñame las cosas románticas.
Colombian_Notes: Language as intimacy tool. Colombians appreciate foreigners learning Spanish. 'Enséñame' = teach me - creates connection opportunity.

New_English: I can try it on
Cultural_Context: Shopping phrase: try on clothing. 'Medir' = measure/try on. Could have playful double meaning in intimate contexts.
Example_Sentence: Me lo puedo medir - a ver si me queda bien.
Colombian_Notes: Retail context primarily. Colombian shopping culture involves trying things on. Can be used playfully about other things 'fitting'.

New_English: I'm going to come / I'm going to orgasm
Cultural_Context: Sexual euphemism. 'Venirse' = to come (orgasm). Direct but common in intimate Colombian conversations. Used during sex or sexting.
Example_Sentence: Me voy a venir - sigue así no pares.
Colombian_Notes: Sexual expression. 'Venirse' standard Colombian term for orgasm. Used by all genders. Direct sexual communication during intimacy.

New_English: Nice to meet you I'm Boris
Cultural_Context: Standard introduction. 'Mucho gusto' = pleased to meet you. Template for introducing yourself in Colombian social contexts.
Example_Sentence: Mucho gusto soy Boris - encantado de conocerte.
Colombian_Notes: Basic Colombian introduction formula. 'Mucho gusto' essential polite phrase. Name follows. Can add profession or context after.

New_English: I'm not ready
Cultural_Context: Boundary-setting phrase. Gender-marked adjective (lista/listo). Used for emotional or physical intimacy. Colombian directness about readiness.
Example_Sentence: No estoy lista para tener relaciones todavía - necesito más tiempo.
Colombian_Notes: Important consent phrase. Colombians respect stated boundaries. Can refer to emotional commitment or physical intimacy. Clear communication.

Spanish: No puedo ahora pero más tarde sí
New_English: I can't right now but later yes
Cultural_Context: Soft decline with future promise. Colombian communication: not rejecting, just timing issue. Shows continued interest.
Example_Sentence: No puedo ahora pero más tarde sí - déjame terminar esto y te llamo.
Colombian_Notes: Keeps door open. Colombian politeness: offer alternative. Shows willingness just bad timing. Maintains connection.

Spanish: No puedo dejar de pensar en ti
New_English: I can't stop thinking about you
Cultural_Context: Romantic confession. 'Dejar de' = stop doing something. Classic expression of preoccupation with romantic interest.
Example_Sentence: No puedo dejar de pensar en ti - estás en mi mente todo el día.
Colombian_Notes: Universal romantic expression, very common in Colombian flirting. Shows emotional investment. Can be early in dating or established relationship.

New_English: I can't resist you
Cultural_Context: Admission of attraction/desire. 'Resistirse' = resist. Sexual/romantic tension acknowledgment. Shows vulnerability to attraction.
Example_Sentence: No puedo resistirme a ti - me vuelves loco cuando me miras así.
Colombian_Notes: Sexually charged confession. Colombians are expressive about desire. Acknowledges power of attraction. Used in intimate contexts.

Spanish: No quiero que te preocupes por mí estoy bien
New_English: I don't want you to worry about me I'm fine
Cultural_Context: Reassurance phrase. 'Preocuparse' = worry. Shows care while maintaining independence. Colombian emotional communication.
Example_Sentence: No quiero que te preocupes por mí estoy bien - solo necesito descansar.
Colombian_Notes: Balancing care with autonomy. Colombian relationships involve checking in. Reassures partner while setting boundary about being okay.

Spanish: No soy fotógrafo pero puedo imaginarnos juntos
New_English: I'm not a photographer but I can picture us together
Cultural_Context: Pick-up line playing with 'imaginar' = imagine/picture. Colombian wordplay flirting. Implies visualizing romantic future together.
Example_Sentence: No soy fotógrafo pero puedo imaginarnos juntos - haríamos una pareja hermosa.
Colombian_Notes: Clever Colombian flirt line. 'Imaginarnos juntos' = picture us together/as couple. Playful way to express romantic interest.

Spanish: No soy matemático pero tú + yo = destino
New_English: I'm not a mathematician but you + me = destiny
Cultural_Context: Mathematical pickup line. Colombian romantic humor. 'Destino' = destiny/fate. Playful but expresses belief in meant-to-be connection.
Example_Sentence: No soy matemático pero tú + yo = destino - creo que el universo nos juntó.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian cheesy romantic line. Math = logic, destiny = fate. Combines rational and romantic. Shows interest through humor.

New_English: I don't have sleep / I'm not sleepy
Cultural_Context: Statement about not being tired. Used late at night implying wanting to stay up - with someone or alone. Context determines meaning.
Example_Sentence: No tengo sueño - podemos seguir hablando si quieres.
Colombian_Notes: Late night phrase. Can be intimate suggestion (not ready to sleep/end evening) or just literal. Colombians stay up late socializing.

New_English: Sorry for not responding sooner
Cultural_Context: Colombian apology for delayed response. Texting culture values timely replies. Shows respect and acknowledges delay.
Example_Sentence: Perdón por no responder antes - estaba en una reunión.
Colombian_Notes: Text etiquette apology. Colombians are responsive texters. Explaining delay shows consideration. Maintains connection.

Spanish: Perdón si te hice sentir mal
New_English: Sorry if I made you feel bad
Cultural_Context: Apology for emotional impact. 'Hacer sentir' = make feel. Colombian emotional awareness and accountability in relationships.
Example_Sentence: Perdón si te hice sentir mal - no era mi intención lastimarte.
Colombian_Notes: Emotional intelligence in Colombian relationships. Taking responsibility for impact even if intention was good. Repair attempt.

New_English: Can I call you for a quick moment
Cultural_Context: Request to call briefly. 'Momentico' = little moment (Colombian diminutive). Shows respect for their time while wanting voice connection.
Example_Sentence: Puedo llamarte un momentico - es más fácil explicarte por teléfono.
Colombian_Notes: 'Momentico' very Colombian. Diminutive softens request. Values voice over text for important/complex topics. Shows consideration.

New_English: Can I pay in installments
Cultural_Context: Financial phrase about payment plans. 'Cuotas' = installments. Relevant for Colombian shopping/economic context. Shows financial planning.
Example_Sentence: Puedo pagar en cuotas - cuántas cuotas me dan para este precio.
Colombian_Notes: Common Colombian question. Economy makes installments standard. 'Cuotas' cultural financial practice. Practical dating consideration.

New_English: Do you want me to pick you up / come get you
Cultural_Context: Offer to pick up someone. 'Pasar por' = pass by for/pick up. Colombian dating courtesy - offering transportation shows care.
Example_Sentence: Quieres que pase por ti o nos vemos allá directamente.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian dating logistics. Offering ride shows interest and chivalry. 'Pasar por' common phrase. Safety and convenience consideration.

Spanish: Quieres que te lleve una pastica o algo
New_English: Do you want me to bring you a pill/medicine or something
Cultural_Context: Caring offer when partner is unwell. 'Pastica' (diminutive of pastilla) = little pill. Shows attentiveness and willingness to help.
Example_Sentence: Quieres que te lleve una pastica o algo para el dolor - puedo pasar por la farmacia.
Colombian_Notes: 'Pastica' Colombian diminutive showing care. Offering medicine/help when partner sick. 'O algo' = or something - open to other needs.

Spanish: Quieres que te pida un taxi
New_English: Do you want me to order you a taxi
Cultural_Context: Offer to arrange transportation. Colombian care-taking in dating. Shows concern for safe travel home.
Example_Sentence: Quieres que te pida un taxi o te quedas - como prefieras.
Colombian_Notes: Safety and logistics. Colombian dating involves coordination. Uber/taxi ordering is caring gesture. Respect for independence while offering help.

New_English: I want something serious with you
Cultural_Context: DTR (define relationship) phrase. 'Algo serio' = something serious/committed. Colombian directness about relationship intentions.
Example_Sentence: Quiero algo serio contigo - no estoy jugando.
Colombian_Notes: Important relationship talk. Colombians value clarity about intentions. 'Algo serio' = exclusivity/commitment. Shows readiness for relationship.

New_English: I want to kiss you
Cultural_Context: Direct expression of desire to kiss. Colombian romantic boldness. Clear communication of physical attraction and intention.
Example_Sentence: Quiero besarte - puedo?
Colombian_Notes: Colombian consent culture: expressing desire then asking permission. Direct but respectful. Physical affection communication.

New_English: I want to sleep with you
Cultural_Context: Ambiguous - can mean literal sleeping together OR sex. 'Dormir' = sleep. Context and relationship stage determine meaning.
Example_Sentence: Quiero dormir contigo abrazados toda la noche.
Colombian_Notes: Can be innocent (cuddling) or sexual. Colombian Spanish uses 'dormir' both ways. Tone and context clarify. Intimate either way.

New_English: I want to start a family with you
Cultural_Context: Serious relationship intention. 'Formar familia' = build/start family. Colombian culture values family. Major commitment statement.
Example_Sentence: Quiero formar una familia contigo - veo un futuro a tu lado.
Colombian_Notes: Big statement in Colombian dating. Family is central value. Shows long-term serious intentions. Usually after dating established.

New_English: I want to make love to you
Cultural_Context: Romantic/sexual expression. 'Hacer el amor' = make love (gentler than 'tener sexo'). Colombian preference for romantic framing of sex.
Example_Sentence: Quiero hacerte el amor despacio y con cariño.
Colombian_Notes: 'Hacer el amor' more romantic than 'coger/tirar'. Colombian preference for emotional + physical. Shows tenderness with desire.

Spanish: Quiero que estemos bien tú y yo
New_English: I want us to be good you and I
Cultural_Context: Relationship maintenance desire. 'Estemos bien' = be okay/good together. Colombian emphasis on harmony and clear communication.
Example_Sentence: Quiero que estemos bien tú y yo - hablemos si hay algo que te molesta.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian relationship value: harmony. 'Estar bien' = good standing. Shows commitment to working through issues. Proactive peace-keeping.

Spanish: Quiero que estemos bien y nos cuidemos
New_English: I want us to be good and take care of each other
Cultural_Context: Mutual care desire. 'Cuidarse' = take care of each other. Colombian relationships emphasize reciprocal caregiving.
Example_Sentence: Quiero que estemos bien y nos cuidemos siempre - eres importante para mí.
Colombian_Notes: 'Nos cuidemos' reciprocal care verb. Colombian relationship foundation: mutual protection and care. Emotional and physical well-being.

New_English: I want to feel you
Cultural_Context: Sensual/sexual expression. 'Sentir' = feel. Physical intimacy desire. Colombian directness about physical connection.
Example_Sentence: Quiero sentirte cerca - extraño tu piel.
Colombian_Notes: Physical/sexual desire. Colombian intimacy language. 'Sentir' multisensory: touch, presence, connection. Used in established intimate relationships.

New_English: I want a future with you
Cultural_Context: Long-term commitment expression. 'Futuro' = future. Colombian seriousness about relationship progression and life partnership.
Example_Sentence: Quiero un futuro contigo - te veo en mis planes.
Colombian_Notes: Major relationship statement. Colombian dating progresses to future talk. Shows integration into life vision. Serious commitment.

New_English: I want to see you soon
Cultural_Context: Expression of eagerness to meet. 'Pronto' = soon. Colombian enthusiasm and impatience to spend time together.
Example_Sentence: Quiero verte pronto - cuándo estás libre.
Colombian_Notes: Standard Colombian dating phrase. Shows interest and initiative. 'Pronto' creates urgency. Leads to planning next meeting.

New_English: What do you want me to do to you
Cultural_Context: Can be practical OR sexual. Context determines meaning. In intimate contexts = sexual invitation to express desires.
Example_Sentence: Qué quieres que te haga - dime y lo hago.
Colombian_Notes: Context-dependent. Helpful OR sexual. In intimate setting = sexual communication about preferences. Colombian openness about pleasure.

New_English: I'm craving something sweet / You look sweet to me
Cultural_Context: 'Antojarse' = have craving. Literal: wanting sweet food. Metaphorical: finding person attractive/sweet. Colombian playful ambiguity.
Example_Sentence: Se me antoja algo dulce - tú.
Colombian_Notes: Double meaning: literal craving OR person as object of desire. Colombian flirty wordplay. 'Antojo' = craving. Can be innocent or flirty.

Spanish: Se me pasa el tiempo volando contigo
New_English: Time flies by with you
Cultural_Context: Romantic compliment. 'Se me pasa' = it passes on me (unintentional). 'Volando' = flying. Enjoys time together so much time disappears.
Example_Sentence: Se me pasa el tiempo volando contigo - las horas parecen minutos.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian romantic expression. Time perception with good company. Shows enjoyment and connection. Quality time appreciation.

Spanish: Si necesitas puedo pasar un ratico
New_English: If you need I can stop by for a little while
Cultural_Context: Supportive offer to visit. 'Ratico' (Colombian diminutive) = little while. Shows availability and care without pressure.
Example_Sentence: Si necesitas puedo pasar un ratico - solo para verte y que sepas que estoy aquí.
Colombian_Notes: 'Ratico' very Colombian. Shows flexibility and support. Offering presence without imposing. Caring gesture in Colombian relationships.

New_English: Without you I am nothing
Cultural_Context: Intense romantic dependency expression. Colombian dramatic romantic style. Shows depth of feeling and importance of person.
Example_Sentence: Sin ti no soy nada mi amor - tú le das sentido a mi vida.
Colombian_Notes: Strong romantic declaration. Colombian emotional expressiveness. Can be beautiful or co-dependent depending on relationship health. Poetic tradition.

New_English: I'm all yours
Cultural_Context: Complete devotion statement. Gender-marked (toda=f, todo=m). Sexual/romantic submission or commitment. Colombian passion expression.
Example_Sentence: Soy toda tuya mi amor - haz conmigo lo que quieras.
Colombian_Notes: Can be romantic commitment OR sexual surrender. Colombian expressiveness about belonging to partner. Intensity varies by context.

New_English: I'm your favorite patient
Cultural_Context: Playful roleplay phrase. Gender-marked. Medical scenario flirting. Colombian playfulness in intimate contexts. Doctor/patient dynamic.
Example_Sentence: Soy tu paciente favorita doctora - necesito un chequeo completo.
Colombian_Notes: Sexual roleplay language. Colombian creativity in intimate play. 'Paciente' = patient. Medical scenarios common flirty theme.

New_English: I'll text you when I arrive
Cultural_Context: Promise to update upon arrival. Colombian safety check-in culture. Shows consideration and keeps partner informed.
Example_Sentence: Te escribo cuando llegue a mi casa - para que estés tranquilo.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian check-in culture. Safety and consideration. 'Escribo' = text/message. Standard after dates or travel.

New_English: I'll text you when I'm leaving / on my way
Cultural_Context: Promise to notify when departing. 'Vaya saliendo' = progressive going out. Colombian time coordination and communication.
Example_Sentence: Te escribo cuando vaya saliendo - así sabes cuándo llego.
Colombian_Notes: 'Ir + gerund' = progressive action. Colombian coordination. Helps partner prepare/know timing. Consideration in dating.

Spanish: Te parece si lo planificamos bien y te aviso
New_English: How about we plan it well and I'll let you know
Cultural_Context: Gentle proposal to organize properly. 'Te parece si' = how about if. Shows thoughtfulness and respect for planning.
Example_Sentence: Te parece si lo planificamos bien y te aviso después - quiero que todo salga perfecto.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian collaborative planning. 'Te parece si' polite suggestion. Shows care about quality of time together. Thoughtful dating.

Spanish: Te parece si nos vemos más tardecito
New_English: How about we meet a bit later
Cultural_Context: Proposal to meet later. 'Tardecito' (diminutive) = bit later. Colombian diminutives soften requests and show flexibility.
Example_Sentence: Te parece si nos vemos más tardecito - como a las ocho.
Colombian_Notes: 'Tardecito' Colombian softening. Shows flexibility. Not canceling, adjusting timing. Respectful scheduling negotiation.

Spanish: Te queda bien a las siete
New_English: Does seven work for you / Is seven good for you
Cultural_Context: Scheduling question. 'Quedar bien' = work well/suit. Colombian dating logistics - confirming time works for both.
Example_Sentence: Te queda bien a las siete o prefieres más tarde.
Colombian_Notes: 'Te queda bien' = does it suit you. Colombian consideration in planning. Offering alternative shows flexibility.

Spanish: Te queda bien por Chapinero/El Poblado/etc
New_English: Does Chapinero/El Poblado/etc work for you
Cultural_Context: Location scheduling. Chapinero (Bogotá), El Poblado (Medellín) are neighborhoods. Shows geographic consideration in planning.
Example_Sentence: Te queda bien por Chapinero o quieres que nos veamos en otro lado.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian city neighborhoods. Logistics matter. Shows willingness to accommodate location preferences. Practical dating consideration.

New_English: I want you for breakfast
Cultural_Context: Sexual innuendo. Playful expression of desire for morning intimacy. Colombian creative food-sex metaphors.
Example_Sentence: Te quiero de desayuno almuerzo y cena.
Colombian_Notes: Sexual Colombian expression. Food = sex metaphor. Playful morning intimacy desire. 'Desayuno' = breakfast. Used in established relationships.

New_English: I love you a lot / I care about you a lot
Cultural_Context: Expression of affection. 'Querer' lighter than 'amar'. Colombian progression: me gustas → te quiero → te amo.
Example_Sentence: Te quiero mucho mi amor - eres muy especial para mí.
Colombian_Notes: 'Querer' = love/want/care. Less intense than 'amar'. Colombian relationship progression middle stage. Safe serious affection.

New_English: I love you a ton / I really care about you
Cultural_Context: Emphatic affection. 'Montón' = ton/heap. Colombian informal intensifier. Shows strong caring in friendly expressive way.
Example_Sentence: Te quiero un montón - gracias por estar siempre.
Colombian_Notes: 'Un montón' Colombian intensifier. More casual than 'te amo'. Shows deep affection playfully. Can be romantic or close friendship.

Spanish: Te voy a comer a besos
New_English: I'm going to eat you up with kisses
Cultural_Context: Playful passionate promise. 'Comer' = eat. Colombian metaphor for intense affection. Shows enthusiasm for physical affection.
Example_Sentence: Te voy a comer a besos cuando te vea.
Colombian_Notes: 'Comer a besos' Colombian expression. Playful intensity. Shows eagerness for physical affection. Passionate but lighthearted.

New_English: I have cramps
Cultural_Context: Period/menstrual cramps. 'Cólicos' = cramps. Colombian directness about menstruation in intimate relationships.
Example_Sentence: Tengo cólicos hoy - por eso no tengo muchas ganas de salir.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian openness about period symptoms. 'Cólicos' menstrual or stomach cramps. Used to explain low energy or canceling plans.

Spanish: Tengo fiebre y la culpa es tuya
New_English: I have a fever and it's your fault
Cultural_Context: Flirty blame. 'Fiebre' literal fever OR metaphorical (passion). Colombian playful accusation that attraction causes physical response.
Example_Sentence: Tengo fiebre y la culpa es tuya - me pones muy caliente.
Colombian_Notes: Double meaning: actual fever OR 'hot' from attraction. Colombian flirty accusation. 'Culpa' = fault. Playful in relationships.

Spanish: Tengo ganas de verte cuándo te sirve
New_English: I want to see you when works for you
Cultural_Context: Expression of desire to meet + respectful scheduling. 'Ganas' = desire/want. Colombian consideration combining eagerness with flexibility.
Example_Sentence: Tengo ganas de verte cuándo te sirve esta semana.
Colombian_Notes: 'Tener ganas de' = feel like/want to. Colombian combination of enthusiasm + respect for schedule. Shows interest without pressure.

New_English: I'm hungry for you / I hunger for you
Cultural_Context: Sexual/romantic metaphor. 'Hambre' = hunger. Colombian passionate expression of desire using food metaphor.
Example_Sentence: Tengo hambre de ti - quiero devorarte.
Colombian_Notes: Sexual Colombian expression. Hunger = desire. 'Hambre' physical need metaphor for passion. Used in intimate established relationships.

Spanish: Tengo hambre pero no de comida
New_English: I'm hungry but not for food
Cultural_Context: Sexual innuendo. Clear implication: hungry for partner not food. Colombian playful indirect sexual communication.
Example_Sentence: Tengo hambre pero no de comida - tengo hambre de ti.
Colombian_Notes: Flirty Colombian expression. Obviously sexual. Creative way to express desire. Food hunger vs body hunger. Playful seduction.

New_English: I really want you / I desire you a lot
Cultural_Context: Strong desire expression. 'Muchas ganas' = strong desire. Can be emotional OR sexual. Colombian directness about wanting someone.
Example_Sentence: Tengo muchas ganas de ti - cuándo nos vemos.
Colombian_Notes: 'Tener ganas' = want/desire. Can be romantic longing OR sexual desire. Intensity shows with 'muchas'. Colombian boldness.

New_English: I'm thirsty for you / I thirst for you
Cultural_Context: Poetic desire expression. 'Sed' = thirst. Colombian romantic metaphor. Implies intense need/craving for person.
Example_Sentence: Tengo sed de ti - necesito sentirte cerca.
Colombian_Notes: Romantic/sexual metaphor. Thirst = intense need. Colombian poetic desire language. More romantic than crude. Passionate longing.

New_English: I have a new toy
Cultural_Context: Innocent OR sexual meaning. 'Juguete' = toy. In intimate contexts = sex toy. Colombian playfulness about introducing novelty.
Example_Sentence: Tengo un juguete nuevo - quieres probarlo.
Colombian_Notes: Context determines meaning. In intimate relationship likely sex toy. Colombian openness about sexual exploration. Playful introduction.

Spanish: Tengo un problema que solo tú puedes resolver
New_English: I have a problem that only you can solve
Cultural_Context: Flirty dependency expression. Playful way to say someone is the solution/answer. Colombian romantic problem-solving.
Example_Sentence: Tengo un problema que solo tú puedes resolver - te necesito.
Colombian_Notes: Romantic line suggesting person is the answer/cure. Colombian dramatic romantic style. Creates importance and need. Flirty vulnerability.

New_English: I have a surprise for you
Cultural_Context: Exciting announcement. 'Sorpresa' = surprise. Colombian enthusiasm for gifts/surprises. Creates anticipation in relationships.
Example_Sentence: Tengo una sorpresa para ti - cierra los ojos.
Colombian_Notes: Colombians love surprises. Builds excitement. Can be gift, plan, or intimate surprise. Creates romantic anticipation.

New_English: All good I'm aware / I'm on it / I'm keeping track
Cultural_Context: Reassurance + awareness. 'Estar pendiente' = being aware/attentive. Colombian commitment to staying informed and involved.
Example_Sentence: Todo bien Estoy pendiente de cómo sigues - avísame si necesitas algo.
Colombian_Notes: 'Estar pendiente' key Colombian value. Shows active attention and care. Reassures while demonstrating attentiveness. Relationship awareness.

Spanish: Todo bien Estoy pendiente de ti
New_English: All good I'm thinking about you / I'm aware of you
Cultural_Context: Specific attention to person. Shows active care and awareness of their situation/feelings. Colombian attentiveness in relationships.
Example_Sentence: Todo bien Estoy pendiente de ti y cómo estás - me preocupo por ti.
Colombian_Notes: 'Pendiente de ti' = focused on you. Colombian care demonstration. Shows person is priority. Emotional attentiveness.

New_English: I'm going to disconnect for a while / take a break from my phone
Cultural_Context: Setting boundaries around technology. 'Desconectarse' = disconnect. Colombian awareness of digital boundaries and self-care.
Example_Sentence: Voy a desconectarme un rato - necesito descansar de las pantallas.
Colombian_Notes: Digital boundary setting. Colombian balance with technology. 'Un rato' = a while. Self-care and presence over constant connectivity.

New_English: I'm coming in five / I'll be there in five
Cultural_Context: Time estimate 'en cinco' = in five (minutes). Note: Colombian 'five minutes' often means 10-15. Flexible time culture.
Example_Sentence: Voy en cinco minutos - ya voy saliendo.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian time flexibility. 'En cinco' rarely literal. Cultural understanding that time is approximate. Shows movement toward arrival.

New_English: I'm running late sorry
Cultural_Context: Common apology for lateness. Colombian time culture more flexible. Acknowledgment + apology standard communication.
Example_Sentence: Voy tarde perdón - salgo en cinco minutos.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian lateness culture. More relaxed about punctuality. Apologizing while updating on status. Standard dating communication.

New_English: I'm already on my way / I'm on my way now
Cultural_Context: Update that departure happened. 'Ya' = already. Colombian communication about movement/travel. Reassures waiting person.
Example_Sentence: Ya voy en camino - llego en quince minutos.
Colombian_Notes: 'Ya' indicates action started. Colombian travel updates. Helps partner track arrival. 'En camino' = in transit/on the way.

New_English: I have condoms
Cultural_Context: Practical sexual readiness. Direct communication about safe sex preparation. Colombian responsibility in sexual situations.
Example_Sentence: Yo tengo condones - no te preocupes.
Colombian_Notes: Sexual health responsibility. Colombian openness about protection. Shows preparedness and care. Consent culture awareness.

New_English: To the right / On the right side
Cultural_Context: Directional phrase. 'Mano derecha' = right hand/side. Colombian direction-giving (less formal than 'a la derecha').
Example_Sentence: Sigue derecho y luego a mano derecha.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian casual directions. 'A mano derecha' more conversational than 'a la derecha'. Used in street directions and navigation.

New_English: To the left / On the left side
Cultural_Context: Directional phrase. 'Mano izquierda' = left hand/side. Colombian informal direction-giving.
Example_Sentence: Gira a mano izquierda en la próxima cuadra.
Colombian_Notes: Informal Colombian directions. 'A mano izquierda' conversational style. Practical in taxi/Uber or meeting up.

New_English: Here we rest by partying / Here resting means partying
Cultural_Context: Colombian party culture statement. 'Rumbear' = party. Playful idea that partying IS resting/relaxing in Colombian culture.
Example_Sentence: Aquí se descansa rumbiando - no conocemos otra forma de relajarnos.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian party culture. 'Rumbear' = party/dance. Cultural joke that partying is how Colombians recharge. Social life centrality.

New_English: Get off here / Get out here
Cultural_Context: Direction to exit vehicle. 'Bajarse' = get down/off. Used in taxis, Ubers, buses. Practical Colombian urban phrase.
Example_Sentence: Bájate aquí que ya llegamos.
Colombian_Notes: Transport language. 'Bajarse' = exit vehicle. Colombian urban life essential. Used with taxis/Ubers when arriving at destination.

Spanish: Dejemos las cosas aquí yo las cuido
Old_English: Dejemos las cosas aquí yo las ...
New_English: Let's leave things here I'll watch them
Cultural_Context: Offer to guard belongings. Colombian social trust and helpfulness. 'Cuidar' = take care/watch. Common at parties/events.
Example_Sentence: Dejemos las cosas aquí yo las cuido mientras bailan.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian social courtesy. Trust culture at parties. Offering to watch belongings while others dance/socialize. Practical kindness.

New_English: Where are you
Cultural_Context: Basic location question. Colombian coordination culture. Essential for meeting up in person.
Example_Sentence: Dónde estás - ya llegué.
Colombian_Notes: Meeting coordination essential. Colombian real-time location checking. Used constantly for meetups, dates, getting together.

New_English: Where should we meet / Where do we meet
Cultural_Context: Planning meeting location. Colombian collaborative planning. Deciding neutral meeting point.
Example_Sentence: Dónde nos encontramos - propones un lugar.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian meeting planning. Collaborative location decision. Shows flexibility and willingness to accommodate.

New_English: Where is the bathroom
Cultural_Context: Essential practical question. 'Quedar' = be located. Colombian politeness in asking for facilities.
Example_Sentence: Disculpa dónde queda el baño.
Colombian_Notes: Practical necessity. 'Quedar' = be located (not 'estar'). Colombian usage for permanent locations. Bathroom is essential question.

New_English: Where is the spot / Where is the place
Cultural_Context: 'Vuelta' (Colombian slang) = place/spot/errand. Asking where specific location is. Very Colombian vocabulary.
Example_Sentence: Dónde queda la vuelta que me dijiste.
Colombian_Notes: 'Vuelta' very Colombian = place/thing/errand. Context determines meaning. Here = location/spot. Essential urban navigation question.

Spanish: Eres la única razón por la que me gusta venir aquí
Old_English: You're the only reason I like...
New_English: You're the only reason I like coming here
Cultural_Context: Romantic compliment. Person makes location special. Colombian way of saying someone's presence transforms ordinary to special.
Example_Sentence: Eres la única razón por la que me gusta venir aquí - sin ti este lugar no tiene sentido.
Colombian_Notes: Romantic Colombian expression. Place becomes meaningful because of person. Shows they are what matters, not location. Deep compliment.

New_English: Is it far or close by / Is it far or nearby
Cultural_Context: Distance inquiry. 'Cerquita' (diminutive) = close by. Colombian question before agreeing to go somewhere.
Example_Sentence: Está lejos o cerquita el restaurante.
Colombian_Notes: Practical Colombian question. 'Cerquita' diminutive of 'cerca'. Assessing distance before committing. Transport and logistics consideration.

Spanish: Me gustas más que un día festivo con puente
New_English: I like you more than a holiday with a long weekend
Cultural_Context: Colombian comparison. 'Puente' = bridge (long weekend). Holidays with bridge days are beloved. Shows person > best thing.
Example_Sentence: Me gustas más que un día festivo con puente - y eso es decir mucho.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian cultural reference. Long weekends (puentes) are treasured. Comparing person to ultimate happiness. Creative compliment.

Spanish: Nos quedamos aquí o vamos allá
Old_English: Nos quedamos aquí o vamos allá...
New_English: Do we stay here or go there / Should we stay here or go there
Cultural_Context: Location decision question. Colombian collaborative planning. Offering choice between staying vs moving.
Example_Sentence: Nos quedamos aquí o vamos allá - como prefieras.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian flexibility and collaboration. Offering partner choice. Shows consideration. Common in dates and social situations.

New_English: Let's sit here / Should we sit here
Cultural_Context: Suggestion or decision to sit at location. Colombian collaborative or decisive depending on tone.
Example_Sentence: Nos sentamos aquí que se ve tranquilo.
Colombian_Notes: Can be suggestion or statement. Colombian collaborative space claiming. 'Aquí' = here. Used at restaurants, parks, events.

New_English: See you tomorrow take care of yourself
Cultural_Context: Goodbye with care. 'Cuidarse' = take care. Colombian affectionate farewells emphasizing wellness and care.
Example_Sentence: Nos vemos mañana cuídate mucho - descansa bien.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian caring goodbyes. 'Cuídate mucho' = take good care. Shows genuine care and affection. Standard sweet farewell.

New_English: Where is it / Around where is it
Cultural_Context: Location inquiry. 'Por dónde' = around where/which area. Colombian casual direction asking.
Example_Sentence: Por dónde queda el sitio - para saber cómo llegar.
Colombian_Notes: 'Por dónde' = which area/zone. Colombian navigation. Less precise than exact address. General location inquiry.

Spanish: Prefieres que vaya yo hasta allá
New_English: Do you prefer that I go there / Would you rather I come to you
Cultural_Context: Considerate offer to travel to partner's location. Colombian flexibility and willingness to accommodate.
Example_Sentence: Prefieres que vaya yo hasta allá o te queda mejor acá.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian dating consideration. Offering to make effort to go to them. Shows flexibility and care. Transport accommodation.

New_English: Go straight / Continue straight
Cultural_Context: Basic direction. 'Derecho' = straight. Essential Colombian navigation instruction.
Example_Sentence: Sigue derecho dos cuadras más.
Colombian_Notes: Navigation essential. 'Derecho' = straight ahead. Basic Colombian direction-giving. Used with taxis, giving directions, walking.

New_English: Go straight two blocks
Cultural_Context: Specific direction. 'Cuadras' = blocks. Colombian urban navigation using block counting.
Example_Sentence: Sigue derecho dos cuadras y ahí es.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian city navigation. Counting blocks ('cuadras') standard distance measure. Practical direction-giving.

New_English: We're friends with benefits
Cultural_Context: Relationship status definition. 'Amigos con derechos' = friends with rights/benefits. Sexual relationship without commitment.
Example_Sentence: Somos amigos con derechos - nada serio solo pasarla bien.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian term for FWB. 'Derechos' = rights/benefits (euphemism). Sexual friends without romantic commitment. Clear boundaries.

New_English: All good all good / Everything's fine everything's fine
Cultural_Context: Repeated reassurance. Emphatic that everything is okay. Colombian communication style emphasizing peace.
Example_Sentence: Todo bien todo bien - no te preocupes por nada.
Colombian_Notes: Repetition emphasizes. Colombian reassurance style. Doubling phrase shows certainty. Calming anxious partner.

New_English: All good calm down / Everything's fine relax
Cultural_Context: Reassurance + calming. 'Tranquila' (f) = calm/relax. Colombian soothing communication when partner is worried.
Example_Sentence: Todo bien tranquila - yo me encargo.
Colombian_Notes: Gendered calming (tranquila=f, tranquilo=m). Colombian reassurance. Shows control of situation. Reduces partner stress.

New_English: Turn to the right / Turn right
Cultural_Context: Direction instruction. 'Voltear' = turn. Colombian navigation vocabulary.
Example_Sentence: Voltea a la derecha en el semáforo.
Colombian_Notes: 'Voltear' Colombian for turn. More common than 'girar'. Navigation essential. Used with driving, walking, giving directions.

New_English: Turn to the left / Turn left
Cultural_Context: Direction instruction. 'Voltear a la izquierda' = turn left. Colombian street directions.
Example_Sentence: Voltea a la izquierda y sigue derecho.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian direction verb 'voltear' = turn. Left turn instruction. Essential urban navigation phrase.

New_English: Cool / Awesome / Great
Cultural_Context: Colombian slang for cool/awesome. Similar to 'chévere'. Positive reaction to something good.
Example_Sentence: Ese plan suena bacán - vamos.
Colombian_Notes: 'Bacán' Colombian approval slang. Similar to chévere. Shows enthusiasm and agreement. Casual positive response.

New_English: Let's dance / We dance / Shall we dance
Cultural_Context: Invitation or statement about dancing. 'Bailar' = dance. Colombian party culture essential. Can be question or suggestion.
Example_Sentence: Bailamos - me encanta esta canción.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian party culture. Dancing is social essential. Can be romantic invitation or friendly suggestion. Tone matters.

New_English: Let's dance close together / We dance pressed together
Cultural_Context: Invitation to close/intimate dancing. 'Pegaditos' (diminutive) = stuck together. Colombian romantic/sexual dancing style.
Example_Sentence: Bailamos pegaditos esta canción.
Colombian_Notes: 'Pegaditos' = pressed close together. Colombian intimate dancing invitation. Romantic/sexual tension. Reggaeton culture. Physical closeness.

Spanish: Cuál es el plato del día
New_English: What's the daily special / What's today's special
Cultural_Context: Restaurant question. 'Plato del día' = daily special. Colombian dining culture inquiry.
Example_Sentence: Cuál es el plato del día - me sirves eso.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian restaurant culture. Daily special ('plato del día') common and often best value. Standard dining question.

New_English: How are you doing / How are things going / How's it going
Cultural_Context: Follow-up check-in question. 'Seguir' = continue. Colombian caring about ongoing situation/health.
Example_Sentence: Cómo sigues del dolor - ya te sientes mejor.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian follow-up care. 'Seguir' = continue/ongoing. Checking on previous concern. Shows continued care and attention.

New_English: Wonderful / Marvelously / Amazingly well
Cultural_Context: Enthusiastic positive response. 'Maravilla' = marvel/wonder. Colombian expressive way to say things are going great.
Example_Sentence: Cómo estás - De maravilla gracias.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian enthusiastic positive response. More excited than just 'bien'. Shows genuine happiness or excellent state.

New_English: Resting is continuing the party / To rest is to keep partying
Cultural_Context: Colombian party culture joke. 'Rumba' = party. Playful idea that continuing to party is how to rest.
Example_Sentence: Aquí descansar es seguir la rumba - no paramos.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian party culture statement. Humorous take on rest = more partying. Social culture and stamina celebration.

New_English: This place is cool / This place is great
Cultural_Context: Approval of location. 'Chévere' = cool/nice. Colombian positive assessment of venue/place.
Example_Sentence: Está chévere este lugar - me gusta el ambiente.
Colombian_Notes: 'Chévere' standard Colombian approval. Assessing venue positively. Used on dates to show appreciation for choice.

New_English: You speak very beautifully / You have a beautiful way of speaking
Cultural_Context: Compliment on speech/communication. 'Bonito' = beautiful. Colombian appreciation for expression style.
Example_Sentence: Hablas muy bonito - me gusta cómo te expresas.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian compliment on communication. Can be literal (accent/voice) or metaphorical (way of expressing). Romantic appreciation.

New_English: You turn me on / You make me hot
Cultural_Context: Sexual expression. 'Calentar' = heat up. Direct statement of sexual attraction/arousal.
Example_Sentence: Me calientas cuando me miras así.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian sexual expression. 'Calentar' = turn on/arouse. Direct communication of attraction. Used in intimate established relationships.

New_English: My head hurts / I have a headache
Cultural_Context: Health complaint. 'Doler' = hurt. Standard explanation for not feeling well or declining activities.
Example_Sentence: Me duele la cabeza - mejor descansamos hoy.
Colombian_Notes: Standard health complaint. Can be literal or excuse. Colombian direct communication about physical state. Used to explain low energy.

New_English: You turned me on / You got me excited
Cultural_Context: Sexual/romantic arousal expression. 'Prender' = turn on (like light). Colombian confession of being aroused by someone.
Example_Sentence: Me prendiste con esa foto que me mandaste.
Colombian_Notes: 'Prender' = turn on/ignite. Colombian sexual arousal expression. Acknowledging attraction/excitement partner caused. Flirty and direct.

New_English: Another juice/beer please
Cultural_Context: Casual request for another drink. 'Porfa' = please (shortened). Colombian casual dining/bar communication.
Example_Sentence: Otro jugo porfa - tengo mucha sed.
Colombian_Notes: 'Porfa' casual Colombian 'por favor'. Informal dining request. Shows comfort and casualness. Social drinking culture.

New_English: Let's hang out / Let's spend time together / Let's pass the time
Cultural_Context: Invitation to spend casual time together. 'Pasar el rato' = hang out. Colombian relaxed socializing.
Example_Sentence: Pasemos el rato hoy - podemos ver una película.
Colombian_Notes: 'Pasar el rato' = hang out casually. Colombian low-key social invitation. Not necessarily romantic, just spending time together.

New_English: How delicious / How nice / How good
Cultural_Context: Enthusiastic approval. 'Rico' = delicious/rich/nice. Colombian versatile positive exclamation for food, experiences, sensations.
Example_Sentence: Qué rico está este plato.
Colombian_Notes: 'Qué rico' versatile Colombian approval. Food, experiences, sensations. Can be innocent or sexual depending on context. Enthusiastic positive.

New_English: How good daddy/mommy / That's so good daddy/mommy
Cultural_Context: Sexual expression. 'Papá/mamá' = daddy/mommy (sexual terms of endearment). Colombian intimate bedroom talk.
Example_Sentence: Qué rico papá sigue así.
Colombian_Notes: Sexual Colombian expression. 'Papá/mamá' used as sexy terms during intimacy. 'Qué rico' = feels so good. Bedroom communication.

New_English: How good it feels / That feels so good
Cultural_Context: Sensual/sexual expression. Can be about physical sensation or experience. Colombian appreciation of feeling.
Example_Sentence: Qué rico se siente estar contigo.
Colombian_Notes: Can be romantic (being together) or sexual (physical sensation). Colombian appreciation expression. 'Sentirse' = to feel. Pleasure acknowledgment.

New_English: What does boleta/chimba/recocha mean
Cultural_Context: Language learning question about Colombian slang. Shows curiosity about local vocabulary. Learning culture through language.
Example_Sentence: Qué significa boleta - lo escucho mucho pero no entiendo.
Colombian_Notes: Shows interest in Colombian slang. 'Boleta' = embarrassment. 'Chimba' = awesome/cool. 'Recocha' = joke/fun. Language learning cultural bridge.

Spanish: Si besarte fuera pecado caminaría feliz al infierno
New_English: If kissing you were a sin I would walk happily to hell
Cultural_Context: Dramatic romantic line. Willing to face consequences for love. Colombian poetic romantic intensity. Religious imagery used romantically.
Example_Sentence: Si besarte fuera pecado caminaría feliz al infierno contigo.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian dramatic romantic expression. Religious culture influences romantic language. Poetic willingness to sacrifice for love. Intense passion statement.

Spanish: Si te sientes mal avísame de una
New_English: If you feel bad let me know right away / If you feel sick tell me immediately
Cultural_Context: Caring instruction. 'De una' = right away/immediately. Colombian attentiveness and care when partner unwell.
Example_Sentence: Si te sientes mal avísame de una para acompañarte.
Colombian_Notes: 'De una' = immediately/right away. Colombian care and responsiveness. Shows priority of partner's wellbeing. Attentive relationship behavior.

Spanish: Si te sientes mejor hablamos esta noche
Old_English: Si te sientes mejor hablamos e...
New_English: If you feel better we'll talk tonight
Cultural_Context: Conditional plan based on health. Shows flexibility and care. Colombian consideration for partner's state.
Example_Sentence: Si te sientes mejor hablamos esta noche - si no descansa tranquilo.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian flexibility around health. Respecting recovery needs. 'Si te sientes mejor' shows care. No pressure if still unwell.

New_English: Super good / Really well
Cultural_Context: Enthusiastic positive response. 'Súper' intensifies 'bien'. Colombian expressive way to say things are going very well.
Example_Sentence: Cómo estás - Súper bien gracias.
Colombian_Notes: 'Súper' Colombian intensifier. More enthusiastic than just 'bien'. Shows genuine positive state. Expressive communication style.

New_English: Would you like to have dinner with me
Cultural_Context: Formal date invitation. 'Te gustaría' = would you like. Colombian polite invitation style for romantic dinner.
Example_Sentence: Te gustaría cenar conmigo el viernes - conozco un lugar bonito.
Colombian_Notes: Colombian formal date invitation. 'Cenar' = dinner. Shows serious romantic interest. Dinner date more formal than coffee/drinks.

New_English: Are we going to party or what / Let's go party or what
Cultural_Context: Enthusiastic party invitation. 'Rumbear' = party. 'O qué' adds emphasis/challenge. Colombian party culture enthusiasm.
Example_Sentence: Vamos a rumbear o qué - no seas aburrido.
Colombian_Notes: 'Rumbear' Colombian = party/go out dancing. 'O qué' creates playful pressure. Party culture central to social life.

New_English: Your kisses drive me crazy
Cultural_Context: Romantic/sexual compliment. 'Volver loco' = drive crazy. Colombian passionate expression about partner's effect.
Example_Sentence: Tus besos me vuelven loco - no puedo resistirme a ti.
Colombian_Notes: 'Volver loco' = drive crazy/make insane. Colombian passionate romantic language. Shows overwhelming effect of partner's affection. Gender-marked adjective.

New_English: I desire you / I want you
Cultural_Context: Sexual desire expression. 'Desear' = desire. More intense than 'quiero'. Colombian direct sexual communication.
Example_Sentence: Te deseo tanto - quiero estar contigo.
Colombian_Notes: 'Desear' stronger than 'querer'. Sexual/romantic desire. Colombian directness about attraction. Used in intimate contexts. Clear communication.

New_English: Come to bed
Cultural_Context: Sexual/intimate invitation. 'Cama' = bed. Direct invitation for intimacy. Colombian bedroom communication.
Example_Sentence: Ven a la cama - te estoy esperando.
Colombian_Notes: Direct sexual invitation. 'Venir a la cama' clear intimacy initiation. Colombian straightforward bedroom communication. Consent and invitation.

New_English: Where can I buy...?
Cultural_Context: Shopping question. 'Comprar' = buy. Colombian practical inquiry for purchasing items.
Example_Sentence: Dónde puedo comprar un cargador por acá.
Colombian_Notes: Standard shopping question. Colombian commercial inquiry. 'Comprar' = purchase. Practical urban navigation for needs.

New_English: Where is my...?
Cultural_Context: Question about lost/misplaced personal item. Colombian common domestic/relationship question.
Example_Sentence: Dónde está mi celular - lo viste.
Colombian_Notes: Common lost item question. Colombian domestic communication. Can be playful or frustrated. Daily life interaction.

New_English: I think that...
Cultural_Context: Opinion introduction. 'Creer' = believe/think. Colombian way to express thoughts/opinions politely.
Example_Sentence: Creo que deberíamos hablar sobre lo que pasó.
Colombian_Notes: Opinion softener. Colombian communication: 'creo que' less direct than stating as fact. Polite opinion expression.

New_English: I think that...
Cultural_Context: Alternative opinion introduction. 'Pensar' = think. Slightly stronger than 'creo que'. Colombian opinion expression.
Example_Sentence: Pienso que sería mejor esperar un poco.
Colombian_Notes: 'Pensar' = think (more deliberate than 'creer'). Colombian opinion sharing. Shows thoughtful consideration before speaking.
